speaker: maya
text: Welcome back to "The Diplomat's Edge." I'm Maya Torres, and today we're tackling something that might seem less glamorous than geopolitics but is absolutely essential - grammar.

speaker: jordan
text: I'm Jordan Hayes, and I cannot overstate how important this is. As a diplomat, you will write constantly - cables, reports, briefings, talking points. Your writing represents the United States government. Grammatical errors undermine your credibility.

speaker: maya
text: The FSOT has an English Expression section specifically testing grammar and usage. What should we expect?

speaker: jordan
text: You'll see sentences with underlined portions. You need to identify whether there's an error and, if so, which portion contains it. You're not rewriting sentences - you're spotting problems.

speaker: maya
text: So this is about developing a sharp eye for errors.

speaker: jordan
text: Exactly. Let's train that eye.

speaker: maya
text: Let's start with the basics. Subject-verb agreement.

speaker: jordan
text: The rule is simple: singular subjects take singular verbs; plural subjects take plural verbs. But in practice, the test writers will make it tricky.

speaker: maya
text: How?

speaker: jordan
text: By putting words between the subject and verb. Look at this sentence: "The collection of antique maps are valuable." What's wrong?

speaker: maya
text: Let me think. "Collection" is the subject, right? Not "maps"?

speaker: jordan
text: Exactly. "Collection" is singular, so it should be "is valuable," not "are valuable." The phrase "of antique maps" is a prepositional phrase that modifies "collection" - it's not the subject.

speaker: maya
text: So I need to strip away the modifiers to find the real subject.

speaker: jordan
text: That's the key skill. Here's another: "The report, along with its appendices, were submitted late." What's wrong?

speaker: maya
text: "Report" is the subject. "Along with its appendices" is just an aside. So it should be "was submitted."

speaker: jordan
text: Perfect. Phrases like "along with," "together with," "as well as," and "in addition to" don't change the number of the subject. They're not the same as "and."

speaker: maya
text: What about "and"?

speaker: jordan
text: "And" usually creates a compound subject that takes a plural verb. "The report and its appendices were submitted." But there's an exception: when two nouns refer to the same thing. "The CEO and founder is speaking today" - if it's one person who is both CEO and founder.

speaker: maya
text: Tricky. What other agreement issues come up?

speaker: jordan
text: Indefinite pronouns are common traps. Some are always singular: "each," "every," "everyone," "everybody," "anyone," "anybody," "no one," "nobody," "someone," "somebody," "either," "neither."

speaker: maya
text: So "Everyone are going" is wrong?

speaker: jordan
text: Right, it should be "Everyone is going." This trips people up because "everyone" refers to multiple people, but grammatically it's singular.

speaker: maya
text: What about "none"?

speaker: jordan
text: "None" is interesting. Traditionally singular, but now often used as plural when referring to countable items. "None of the reports was submitted" is traditional; "None of the reports were submitted" is common in modern usage. For the test, I'd lean toward singular.

speaker: maya
text: What about "either" and "neither"?

speaker: jordan
text: When used alone, they're singular. "Either is acceptable." "Neither was approved." But in "either...or" and "neither...nor" constructions, the verb agrees with the closer subject: "Neither the manager nor the employees were happy." "Neither the employees nor the manager was happy."

speaker: maya
text: The order matters?

speaker: jordan
text: The order matters for which sounds right, but grammatically you match the closer noun.

speaker: maya
text: What about collective nouns like "team" or "committee"?

speaker: jordan
text: In American English, they're usually singular. "The committee has decided." "The team is winning." In British English, they're often plural: "The team are playing well." For the FSOT, use American conventions - singular.

speaker: maya
text: Let's talk about pronouns.

speaker: jordan
text: Pronouns must agree with their antecedents in number and gender. And the antecedent must be clear.

speaker: maya
text: Give me an example of an agreement error.

speaker: jordan
text: "Each diplomat must submit their credentials." This is increasingly common in speech, but grammatically, "each" is singular, so traditional grammar says it should be "his or her credentials."

speaker: maya
text: But isn't "their" used as a singular pronoun now?

speaker: jordan
text: This is evolving. Singular "they" is widely accepted in informal writing and when the gender is unknown or non-binary. But in formal contexts and on the FSOT, traditional agreement is safer. "Each diplomat must submit his or her credentials" or rephrase: "All diplomats must submit their credentials."

speaker: maya
text: What about unclear antecedents?

speaker: jordan
text: Very common error. "When the ambassador met with the foreign minister, he expressed concern." Who expressed concern? The pronoun "he" could refer to either person.

speaker: maya
text: How do you fix it?

speaker: jordan
text: Name the person: "When the ambassador met with the foreign minister, the ambassador expressed concern." Or restructure: "The ambassador expressed concern during his meeting with the foreign minister."

speaker: maya
text: What about pronoun case errors?

speaker: jordan
text: These show up too. "Between you and I" is wrong - it should be "between you and me." "You and me" are objects of the preposition "between," so you use objective case.

speaker: maya
text: I hear "between you and I" all the time.

speaker: jordan
text: It's hypercorrection. People learn that "me" is often wrong ("Me and him went to the store" should be "He and I went"), so they overcorrect. Test yourself by removing the other person: "Between I" sounds wrong; "between me" is correct.

speaker: maya
text: What about "who" versus "whom"?

speaker: jordan
text: "Who" is subjective case (like "he"); "whom" is objective case (like "him"). "Who wrote this report?" - "who" is the subject. "To whom should I send this?" - "whom" is the object of "to."

speaker: maya
text: Is there a trick to remember?

speaker: jordan
text: The "he/him" test. Rephrase the question as a statement using "he" or "him." If "him" fits, use "whom." "I should send this to him" - so "to whom."

speaker: maya
text: What about "whoever" and "whomever"?

speaker: jordan
text: Same logic. "Whoever" is subjective, "whomever" is objective. But here's the trick: look at the whole clause. "Give it to whoever wants it." Even though it follows "to," the subject of "wants it" is "whoever," so it's correct.

speaker: maya
text: What about tense errors?

speaker: jordan
text: Verb tense should be consistent within a passage unless there's a logical reason to shift. "The ambassador arrived at the meeting and presents his credentials" - that's wrong because it shifts from past to present.

speaker: maya
text: That seems obvious.

speaker: jordan
text: It is when it's that clear. The FSOT will be subtler. The issue is often sequence of tenses - making sure past, past perfect, and other tenses relate correctly.

speaker: maya
text: Explain past perfect.

speaker: jordan
text: Past perfect ("had done") describes something that happened before another past event. "By the time the summit began, the negotiators had already reached an agreement." The reaching happened before the beginning, so "had reached."

speaker: maya
text: When do I need past perfect?

speaker: jordan
text: When you're describing two past events and need to show which happened first. "I realized I left my passport at home" is fine in casual speech, but "I realized I had left my passport" is more precise - the leaving happened before the realizing.

speaker: maya
text: What about conditional tenses?

speaker: jordan
text: Common error source. "If I would have known, I would have attended." This is wrong. The correct form is "If I had known, I would have attended." The "if" clause takes past perfect, not "would have."

speaker: maya
text: That one sounds wrong even when it's right.

speaker: jordan
text: It's a frequent error in speech. But the pattern is: "If [past perfect], [would have + past participle]." "If she had asked, I would have helped."

speaker: maya
text: What about present vs. past in reported speech?

speaker: jordan
text: In formal writing, reported speech usually shifts back in time. "He said that he was ready" (not "is ready"). But if something is still true, present tense is acceptable: "She explained that the Earth is round."

speaker: maya
text: Let's talk about parallelism. What is it?

speaker: jordan
text: Parallelism means using the same grammatical structure for items in a list or comparison. It makes writing clearer and more elegant.

speaker: maya
text: Give me an example of a parallelism error.

speaker: jordan
text: "The new policy is efficient, cost-effective, and reduces waste." See the problem?

speaker: maya
text: The first two are adjectives, but the third is a verb phrase.

speaker: jordan
text: Exactly. It should be "efficient, cost-effective, and waste-reducing" or restructured: "The new policy is efficient and cost-effective and reduces waste."

speaker: maya
text: What about longer constructions?

speaker: jordan
text: The same principle. "The training program includes lectures on history, workshops to develop skills, and case study analysis." The three items have different structures: noun phrase, infinitive phrase, noun phrase. Better: "The training program includes lectures on history, workshops on skills development, and analyses of case studies."

speaker: maya
text: Is this a common test item?

speaker: jordan
text: Very common. Look for lists of three or more items and check that they all have the same grammatical form.

speaker: maya
text: What about comparisons?

speaker: jordan
text: Comparisons need parallel elements too. "She likes reading more than to write" is wrong. It should be "She likes reading more than writing" or "She likes to read more than to write."

speaker: maya
text: Both forms compared should match.

speaker: jordan
text: Right. And make sure comparisons are complete and logical. "The policy in France is different from America" is wrong - you're comparing a policy to a country. It should be "different from the policy in America" or "different from America's."

speaker: maya
text: What about correlative conjunctions?

speaker: jordan
text: Correlative conjunctions are pairs that work together: "both...and," "either...or," "neither...nor," "not only...but also," "whether...or." Whatever follows the first must be grammatically parallel to what follows the second.

speaker: maya
text: Give me an example.

speaker: jordan
text: "The report not only analyzed the data but also recommendations were made." Wrong. What follows "not only" is a verb phrase; what follows "but also" starts with a noun. Correct: "The report not only analyzed the data but also made recommendations."

speaker: maya
text: So I look for what comes right after each part of the pair.

speaker: jordan
text: Exactly. "Both the ambassador and the consul" - two nouns. "Either accept the terms or negotiate further" - two verb phrases. The elements must match.

speaker: maya
text: What about modifier problems?

speaker: jordan
text: Two main issues: dangling modifiers and misplaced modifiers. Both can create confusing or unintentionally funny sentences.

speaker: maya
text: What's a dangling modifier?

speaker: jordan
text: A modifier "dangles" when the word it's supposed to modify isn't actually in the sentence, or isn't in the right position. Classic example: "Walking into the room, the painting caught my eye." Who's walking? The painting?

speaker: maya
text: So "walking into the room" should modify whoever is walking.

speaker: jordan
text: Right. "Walking into the room, I noticed the painting" - now "I" is right after the modifier and is the one doing the walking.

speaker: maya
text: These can be tricky to spot.

speaker: jordan
text: They can. The key is asking: "Who or what is doing the action in the modifier?" and making sure that person or thing appears right after the modifier.

speaker: maya
text: What about misplaced modifiers?

speaker: jordan
text: A misplaced modifier is in the sentence but in the wrong place. "The diplomat only speaks French" means she does nothing but speak French - she doesn't write it or read it. "The diplomat speaks only French" means French is the only language she speaks.

speaker: maya
text: Placement of "only" is a big one.

speaker: jordan
text: It changes meaning significantly. Put "only" immediately before the word or phrase it modifies. "He only recommended three books" vs. "He recommended only three books."

speaker: maya
text: Any other common modifier issues?

speaker: jordan
text: Squinting modifiers - ones that could modify what comes before or after. "Employees who work quickly get promoted" - does "quickly" modify "work" or "get promoted"? Restructure for clarity: "Employees who work at a quick pace get promoted."

speaker: maya
text: What about phrases like "having been..."?

speaker: jordan
text: These need to modify the right noun. "Having been revised several times, the committee finally approved the document." Who was revised? The committee? No - the document was revised. Better: "Having been revised several times, the document was finally approved by the committee."

speaker: maya
text: So the subject of the main clause should be what the opening phrase modifies.

speaker: jordan
text: That's the rule. When you see a sentence starting with a participial phrase, immediately check that the subject of the main clause is what's doing the action in that phrase.

speaker: maya
text: What are other common errors on the FSOT?

speaker: jordan
text: Let's go through some frequent ones. Affect vs. Effect: "Affect" is usually a verb; "effect" is usually a noun. "The policy will affect the economy." "The policy will have an effect on the economy."

speaker: maya
text: Are there exceptions?

speaker: jordan
text: A few. "Effect" can be a verb meaning "to bring about" - "to effect change." "Affect" as a noun is a psychology term. But 95% of the time, affect is a verb and effect is a noun.

speaker: maya
text: What else?

speaker: jordan
text: Fewer vs. Less: "Fewer" for countable things; "less" for uncountable things. "Fewer reports" but "less information." "Fewer dollars" but "less money."

speaker: maya
text: That one I know from grocery stores.

speaker: jordan
text: laughs "10 items or fewer" - they often get it wrong! Next: Farther vs. Further. "Farther" for physical distance; "further" for metaphorical extent. "The embassy is farther down the street." "Let's discuss this further."

speaker: maya
text: Are these tested often?

speaker: jordan
text: They come up. Here's another: Lie vs. Lay. "Lie" means to recline (no object): "I lie down." Past tense: "I lay down yesterday." "Lay" means to put something down (requires an object): "I lay the book on the table." Past tense: "I laid the book on the table."

speaker: maya
text: This one is confusing because "lay" appears in both.

speaker: jordan
text: It's the most confused pair in English. "The book is lying on the table" - present tense, no object. "She laid the documents on the desk" - past tense, has an object.

speaker: maya
text: Any other pairs?

speaker: jordan
text: Who vs. That: Use "who" for people, "that" for things. "The diplomat who wrote the report" not "that wrote." But "the report that was submitted" is correct.

speaker: maya
text: What about which vs. that?

speaker: jordan
text: For things, "that" introduces essential information (no commas), "which" introduces non-essential information (with commas). "Reports that are late will be rejected" - we're specifying which reports. "The report, which was submitted late, was still accepted" - we're adding extra information about a specific report.

speaker: maya
text: The comma is the key.

speaker: jordan
text: Exactly. If you can remove the clause and the sentence still makes sense and has the same meaning, use "which" with commas.

speaker: maya
text: What about double negatives?
chapter: SEGMENT 7: DOUBLE NEGATIVES AND FAULTY COMPARISONS (5 minutes)

speaker: jordan
text: In standard English, double negatives are generally wrong. "I don't have no concerns" should be "I don't have any concerns" or "I have no concerns."
chapter: SEGMENT 7: DOUBLE NEGATIVES AND FAULTY COMPARISONS (5 minutes)

speaker: maya
text: That seems straightforward.
chapter: SEGMENT 7: DOUBLE NEGATIVES AND FAULTY COMPARISONS (5 minutes)

speaker: jordan
text: The tricky ones are subtler. "Hardly" and "scarcely" are already negative, so "I can't hardly wait" is a double negative - it should be "I can hardly wait."
chapter: SEGMENT 7: DOUBLE NEGATIVES AND FAULTY COMPARISONS (5 minutes)

speaker: maya
text: I didn't think of those as negatives.
chapter: SEGMENT 7: DOUBLE NEGATIVES AND FAULTY COMPARISONS (5 minutes)

speaker: jordan
text: They're quasi-negatives. Same with "barely" and "rarely." Don't add "not" or "n't" to them.
chapter: SEGMENT 7: DOUBLE NEGATIVES AND FAULTY COMPARISONS (5 minutes)

speaker: maya
text: What about comparisons?
chapter: SEGMENT 7: DOUBLE NEGATIVES AND FAULTY COMPARISONS (5 minutes)

speaker: jordan
text: Several issues. First, compare like things. "The GDP of China is larger than Japan" - wrong, because you're comparing GDP to a country. "The GDP of China is larger than that of Japan."
chapter: SEGMENT 7: DOUBLE NEGATIVES AND FAULTY COMPARISONS (5 minutes)

speaker: maya
text: Use "that of" to refer back.
chapter: SEGMENT 7: DOUBLE NEGATIVES AND FAULTY COMPARISONS (5 minutes)

speaker: jordan
text: Right. Also, be complete with comparisons. "The new policy is better" - better than what? In formal writing, complete the comparison: "better than the previous policy."
chapter: SEGMENT 7: DOUBLE NEGATIVES AND FAULTY COMPARISONS (5 minutes)

speaker: maya
text: What about superlatives?
chapter: SEGMENT 7: DOUBLE NEGATIVES AND FAULTY COMPARISONS (5 minutes)

speaker: jordan
text: Use comparatives for two things, superlatives for three or more. "Between the two options, this is the better one" - not "best." "Among all the options, this is the best."
chapter: SEGMENT 7: DOUBLE NEGATIVES AND FAULTY COMPARISONS (5 minutes)

speaker: maya
text: Any specific tips for the English Expression section?

speaker: jordan
text: Several. First, read the entire sentence before looking at the underlined portions. Understand the whole meaning first.

speaker: maya
text: Why?

speaker: jordan
text: Because errors often relate to other parts of the sentence. A verb might be wrong because of a subject that appears much earlier. A pronoun might be unclear because you need to know all the possible antecedents.

speaker: maya
text: What next?

speaker: jordan
text: Check each underlined portion systematically. Ask: Is this a subject-verb agreement situation? Is there a pronoun issue? Is there a modifier problem? Go through your checklist.

speaker: maya
text: And if nothing seems wrong?

speaker: jordan
text: "No error" is always an option, and it's often correct. Don't second-guess yourself into finding errors that aren't there. If nothing violates the rules we've discussed, choose "no error."

speaker: maya
text: How much time should I spend?

speaker: jordan
text: Don't rush, but don't agonize. If you're stuck on a question, mark it and move on. Come back if you have time. Your first instinct is often right.

speaker: maya
text: Should I practice?

speaker: jordan
text: Absolutely. Find practice tests - there are FSOT prep resources available. The more sentences you analyze, the faster you'll spot errors.

speaker: maya
text: Jordan, this has been incredibly detailed. My head is swimming with rules.

speaker: jordan
text: That's normal. Grammar mastery takes practice. But you now have the framework. Keep practicing, and these rules will become instinctive.

speaker: maya
text: Next episode is our last one - sentence structure and style. How to write clearly and effectively.

speaker: jordan
text: We'll cover everything from sentence variety to wordiness to common style problems. It's the finishing touch on your writing toolkit.

speaker: maya
text: Thanks for listening, everyone. Until next time, keep practicing those sentences.

speaker: jordan
text: See you next time on The Diplomat's Edge.
